G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts remains the child’s home state and the original custody determination was made by this Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts remains the child’s home state and the original custody determination was made by this Court.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, including G.L. c. 209B, because Massachusetts remains the child’s home state and the original custody determination was made by this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and applicable Massachusetts domestic relations statutes.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In determining a child’s best interests, the Court must evaluate, among other things, the child’s age and developmental needs, the child’s adjustment to home, school, and community, the desirability of maintaining continuity in the child’s environment, and the ability of each parent to provide for the child’s emotional, educational, and physical needs. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–43; Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–96; see also G.L. c. 208, § 31.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial divorce judgment involving custody and removal of children to another country, not a post‑judgment modification based on changed circumstances. Nowhere does the court discuss the standard for modifying an existing custody or support order upon a change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the proposition about when a change in circumstances warrants modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change...

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly applies and quotes the Massachusetts standard that a custody modification must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties and that the change must be conducive to the child’s welfare. The court then evaluates whether such a change existed here and finds none, thereby reaffirming that changes affecting the child’s welfare may warrant modification, but that standard was not met on these facts. This aligns with the proposition about when modification is warranted.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case focusing on interpreting G. L. c. 208, § 30 and the ‘best interests of the child’ standard where parents share joint physical custody. It does not discuss the general standard for modification of custody or support based on a ‘change in circumstances’ affecting the child’s welfare, nor does it state that such changed circumstances may warrant modification. The only ‘change in circumstances’ language appears in a quoted ALI Principles passage, not as a Massachusetts appellate holding, so this case does not provide authority for the broad modification proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]….’”

*Macaulay v. Macaulay*, 458 Mass. 987 (2.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/child support modification case, but the removal analysis is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test, not by the generic ‘change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare’ standard. While the father’s complaint for modification of child support did allege a material and substantial change of circumstances, the opinion does not articulate or discuss the broad principle that changes in the parties’ or child’s circumstances affecting the child’s welfare may warrant modification. It therefore does not serve as direct authority for the proposition claimed.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California. Sometime thereafter, the father filed his own complaint for modification, wherein he sought to (1) reduce his child support obligation to the mother due to the financial support she receives from her new husband… The cases were consolidated and tried together.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns initial divorce, custody, visitation, a 209A order, removal, and a prenuptial agreement; it does not discuss modification standards for existing custody or support orders. The court nowhere states that a change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare may warrant modification, nor does it apply any modification framework. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about modification based on changed circumstances.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt:
In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child... The findings are amply supported by the evidence and demonstrate that the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.

... In light of the fact that more than three years have passed since the judgment was entered and the mother and the child relocated to Illinois, we conclude that a further evidentiary hearing is required to enable a judge to make a decision whether the mother’s request for removal to a specific State is warranted on the basis of a contemporaneous record.

*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what standard applies to modification of a judgment to allow removal of children from Massachusetts (the G.L. c. 208, § 30 “real advantage” / best interests standard), and contrasts that with the more demanding “countervailing equities” standard for modifying surviving separation agreements. It does not articulate any general rule that a change in the circumstances of the parties or child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification; rather, it focuses on statutory removal standards and the primacy of the child’s best interests over contractual terms. Thus it does not support the broad, generalized proposition claimed.
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 (199.relevant_excerpt:
“Where a separation agreement is incorporated in a divorce judgment and survives as an independent contract, it is not an absolute bar to subsequent modification of the judgment. Ryan v. Ryan, 371 Mass. 430, 432 (1976).

General Laws c. 208, § 30, and the standard of proof which it requires cannot be written off by the parties. The best interests of the child will control where there is a question as to whether the child will be removed from the Commonwealth. The jurisdiction of the Probate Court over the minor children of divorced parties may not be ousted by the terms of a separation agreement…”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the G.L. c. 209C, § 20 standard that a modification of custody requires a “substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child,” but only in passing and expressly declines to apply or discuss it. The court resolves the case as an initial custody determination under § 10(a), not as a modification case, and does not state or reaffirm any broader rule about when changed circumstances warrant modification. Therefore it does not provide support for the proposition about modification based on changed circumstances.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’ Id. … We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20…”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for modification of custody orders based on a material change in circumstances affecting the child's welfare. Custody of Vaughn is an appeal from an initial custody judgment and addresses how domestic violence must be considered in best-interest and joint custody determinations, not when or how a prior custody judgment may be modified upon changed circumstances. The opinion contains no discussion of the modification standard or a requirement of changed circumstances as a predicate to altering an existing custody order.

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a change in the circumstances of the parties or the child that affects the child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses modification standards under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and confirms that a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” is required and that any modification must be necessary in the best interests of the children. The court identifies the mother’s remarriage as such a material and substantial post‑divorce change and treats it as a circumstance that can affect the children’s welfare and justify modification. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts appellate courts hold that changed circumstances affecting a child’s welfare may warrant modification.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’). Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances….”
